title: 106_hr4108
content: The "Secure Our Schools Act" is a matching grant program for school security authorized under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Attorney General can provide grants to improve security at schools by using metal detectors, locks, lighting, security assessments, training, and coordination with law enforcement. The Attorney General may give preferential consideration to grant applications from jurisdictions with demonstrated need for improved security and financial assistance. Grants under this program cannot exceed 50% of program costs, and matching funds can be provided by Congress for law enforcement functions on Indian lands. The Attorney General may waive or alter requirements for recipients with financial need. Grants will be distributed equitably across different regions and areas. Up to 2% of funds can be reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 2702. APPLICATIONS. To request a grant under this part, the chief executive of a State, local government, or Indian tribe must submit an application to the Attorney General with detailed explanations of fund usage and how activities will align with the grant's purpose. The application must also include an assurance of consultation with various professionals to ensure the funded improvements are effective. The Attorney General will establish guidelines within 90 days of the enactment of this part for grant applications to prevent school violence. The improvements funded must align with a comprehensive approach and be tailored to each school's needs. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress by November 30th detailing the grants funded, funds provided, and activities carried out under this part. Definitions for "school," "unit of local government," and "Indian tribe" are provided in this section. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2001-2003: $60,000,000 each year.
